title: Gold-Standard Rubric Structure
purpose: Provide clear, consistent, and fair assessment guidelines aligned with ideal answers and learning objectives.

frameworks.name: Bloom's Taxonomy
frameworks.description: Classifies cognitive skills from recall to creation.

frameworks.name: SOLO Taxonomy
frameworks.description: Five levels of understanding, from Prestructural to Extended Abstract.

frameworks.name: AAC&U VALUE Rubrics
frameworks.description: Institutional-level tools for key higher education competencies.

details: Map each criterion to specific outcomes.
Use clear action verbs from Bloom's taxonomy aligned with cognitive levels when generating questions.
Limit criteria and levels for usability.
Frame levels as stages of mastery.
Consistency across raters; fairness for students.

steps: Write a scientifically accurate ideal answer.
No title and purpose needed in the output.
Develop performance bands: Comprehensive, Competent, Partial, Limited.
Map bands to ideal answer elements.

example_rubric.question: Explain why it is difficult to classify viruses as living organisms.

levels.description: Clearly explains that viruses exhibit some characteristics of living organisms, such as reproduction and evolution, but only within a host cell. Justifies that because viruses cannot independently carry out metabolism or reproduce outside a host, it is difficult to classify them as truly living.
Explains that viruses show characteristics of living things but does not fully clarify why this makes classification difficult or omits detail about the dependence on a host cell.
Describes some characteristics viruses share with living organisms but lacks explanation on the challenges of classification or the importance of host dependence.
Does not mention relevant characteristics of viruses or fails to explain why classifying them as living organisms is difficult.
